newsitem.title: USA: ADR REPORT - Latam ADRs fall on peso, politics.
newsitem.headline: ADR REPORT - Latam ADRs fall on peso, politics.

text.p: Latin American shares fell on Wednesday on worries about the Mexican peso and Argentine political concerns, traders said.
Luxury goods makers also saw share prices soften as American Depositary Receipts (ADRs) largely followed the New York markets lower.
One trader in Latin ADRs said, "There is only bad news, and no news to be buying on. The whole market is focusing on the peso."
The peso was battered on spot markets amid a speculative onslaught by Mexican and foreign investors. The benchmark 48-hour peso opened 8.5 centavos weaker at 7.8650/7.8750 a dollar.

The currency also was hit by comments from Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist Rudiger Dornbusch. In a newspaper interview, Dornbusch said the peso should be 20 percent lower than at current levels, or nine pesos to the dollar.
Among Mexican ADRs, Telefonos de Mexico S.A. was off 1/8 to 30-5/8 in early trade.
Argentine shares also were hit by continuing allegations of corruption made by former Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo against President Carlos Menem. Telefonica de Argentina was off 1/8 to 22-1/2.
In Brazil, state telecommunications company Telebras fell 1-1/8 to 76-7/8 on speculation the company would report nine-month earnings below expectations.
Brazilian shares also were hurt by Senate passage of a measure that would impose a 0.2 percent tax on financial transactions.

Luxury and brand-name retail stocks softened, with Fila Holdings SpA off 1-7/8 to 81-1/2 and Gucci Group NV off 5/8 to 73-1/8. Traders said the sector had lost some luster after strong interest early this year.
British Sky Broadcasting Group Plc fell 3-3/4 to 61-1/8 after Tuesday's cable merger involving Cable & Wireless Plc and a negative ruling from Britain's telecommunications regulator.
Among 441 selected ADR stocks, 159 had declined and 72 advanced by late morning. Volume was 23 million shares.
